unnormalised: Someone asked me about emergency medicine in India, and I thought I'd share some basics. Firstly, knowing who to call is crucial. 108 is the emergency number for ambulance services in most states. Keep that number handy. Many private hospitals like Apollo, Max, and Fortis also have their own ambulance services, so knowing their direct numbers for your area can be a lifesaver.

One hundred and eight is the emergency number for ambulance services in most states. Keep that number handy. Many private hospitals like Apollo, Max, and Fortis also have their own ambulance services, so knowing their direct numbers for your area can be a life saver.

unnormalised: Next, what constitutes an emergency? Chest pain, especially if it's radiating down the left arm, is a definite red flag. This could be a heart attack, and time is of the essence. Similarly, sudden paralysis or weakness on one side of the body could indicate a stroke. Get the person to the nearest hospital ASAP. Keep an eye out for difficulty breathing, uncontrolled bleeding, or severe head injuries – all require immediate medical attention. Remember, early intervention often determines the outcome.

unnormalised: Regarding first aid, CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation) is a vital skill. There are numerous online resources and training centers that teach this. The Indian Red Cross Society offers CPR training courses. Knowing basic first aid can stabilize a patient until professional help arrives. For instance, applying direct pressure to a bleeding wound can significantly reduce blood loss. In case of fractures, try to immobilize the limb with a splint (a rolled-up newspaper works in a pinch) to prevent further injury.

unnormalised: It's also important to know which hospitals in your area are equipped to handle different types of emergencies. AIIMS (All India Institute of Medical Sciences) hospitals are generally well-equipped, but private hospitals often have specialized cardiac or trauma centers. Having a list of nearby hospitals with their contact information and specialties can save valuable time. It’s a good idea to find out the nearest hospital which has a dedicated emergency dept.

unnormalised: Finally, remember to communicate clearly with the emergency responders. Provide them with the patient’s age, medical history (if known), symptoms, and any medications they are currently taking. Mention any allergies to medications. Accurate and concise information helps the medical team prepare and provide the most appropriate treatment. For example, telling them "Patient is Rakesh, 62 years old, history of diabetes, experiencing chest pain since 15 minutes" is much more helpful than just saying "he has chest pain".
